title: Is it improper to use semicolons in dialogue? - Quora

response.answer_text: I once talked to a guy who spoke in beautifully sculpted parallel clauses. There’s no way you could reproduce that in print without semicolons. - If you list three or more things in series, and one or more of the things includes a comma, then you have to use semicolons. Thus: “What kind of sandwiches did I bring? I brought ham; turkey; and bacon, lettuce, and tomato.” That sentence is a natural one; it doesn’t sound stilted or weird; it is perfectly good dialogue; and it requires semicolons to be represented in print. (If I were writing that last sentence as dialogue, I would probably replace the semicolons with periods so as not to offend people who don’t think semicolons are natural. But maybe not, because, you know, screw them.) - As a general rule, you want your written dialogue to evoke the way people actually talk. You don’t want your reader to think, “nobody would actually say that.” So, arguably, you want short sentences, sentence fragments, sentences that trail off, garbled sentences, mistakes and corrections, and frequent interruptions. Which would make for a lousy read. If you’ve ever read a transcript of a conversation, you know how offputting reality is. So the compromise is to keep sentences short—which means you don’t need many semicolons—and to avoid the wall-of-text by interrupting every three lines or so to, say, let another character speak or to do a physical action. - Some people will say that not using semicolons in speech is a rule. Often enough, those people don’t know how to use semicolons anyway. I had a woman tell me once, in a critique group, that she didn’t want to see a semicolon in fiction. Not just in dialogue, but anywhere in fiction. I refrained from telling her that she should keep her affliction to herself.

No, it’s fine. Subtle changes in tone of voice might suggest two sentences are connected. Written language doesn’t have tone of voice, so we have to translate that into some other communicative device. In this case a semicolon works fine. Always bear in mind that because so much of our communication depends on nonverbal cues like body language, or subtle variations of tone and timing, if you simply transcribe exactly what is said, word for word, you will not be capturing the flavor of the original conversation. The goal of dialogue is *not* simply to produce an accurate transcript of a conversation, but to find a way to capture all that is being communicated.
